metadata.copyright_compliance: Original content based on general medical knowledge

statement.text: Transmetatarsal amputation removes the forefoot at the metatarsal level while preserving heel and midfoot function, requiring adequate plantar skin flap and perfusion for success.
statement.formal: Level: Through metatarsal shafts (typically mid-metatarsal); Healing requirement: Ankle pressure >70 mmHg or ABI >0.50; Healing rate: 60-85% depending on perfusion; Function: Allows prosthetic-free ambulation

explanation.intuition: When forefoot gangrene is too extensive for toe amputation but the heel is viable, removing the front of the foot preserves the ability to walk with just a shoe filler - much better than losing the entire leg.
explanation.key_insight: TMA preserves the heel, which is the foundation of ambulation - patients can walk without a prosthesis using only a shoe filler.
explanation.technical_details: Transmetatarsal amputation transects all metatarsal bones at the mid-shaft level, preserving the tarsals and heel. A long plantar flap (from the ball of the foot) is essential for durable weight-bearing coverage. The incision is made in a fish-mouth pattern with a shorter dorsal and longer plantar component. Adequate perfusion (ankle pressure >70 mmHg, toe pressure >30 mmHg at ankle level) is necessary for healing. Equinus deformity is a common complication requiring Achilles lengthening.
common_misconceptions: TMA patients need leg prosthesis - FALSE, can walk with shoe filler only
TMA always heals if toes heal - FALSE, different perfusion requirements
Dorsal and plantar flaps should be equal - FALSE, plantar flap must be longer
TMA is always better than BKA - FALSE, failed TMA delays rehabilitation

absolute: Gangrene extending to midfoot or heel
relative: Severe peripheral neuropathy with prior contralateral amputation

incision.principle: Plantar flap 2-3 cm longer than dorsal

achilles_management.technique: Percutaneous triple hemisection or open Z-lengthening
achilles_management.timing: At time of TMA or as staged procedure

immediate: Posterior splint or cast to prevent equinus
long_term: Regular skin and contralateral foot checks

definition.@value: Amputation through the metatarsal bones to remove the forefoot while preserving heel function and prosthesis-free ambulation.

sources.reference: IWGDF Guidelines on Diabetic Foot Ulcers

learning_objectives: Describe the surgical technique including plantar flap design
Explain the importance of Achilles lengthening
Apply perfusion criteria for TMA healing prediction
clinical_pearls: Plantar flap must be longer than dorsal - the ball of foot skin covers the stump
Always consider prophylactic Achilles lengthening to prevent equinus
Ankle pressure >70 mmHg predicts TMA healing
TMA preserves ambulation without prosthesis - just needs shoe filler
Failed TMA delays rehabilitation - select patients carefully
